liveAlbums.description: Any Given Thursday is a live CD/DVD by John Mayer, recorded on September 12, 2002, at the Oak Mountain Amphitheater in Birmingham, Alabama, during the Room for Squares tour. The album peaked at #17 on the Billboard 200 chart and features mostly songs from Room for Squares, along with several covers, including 'Lenny' by Stevie Ray Vaughan and 'Message in a Bottle' by The Police. Covers have become a regular feature in Mayer's live shows.

liveAlbums.description: Try! is the debut live album by the John Mayer Trio, recorded at the House of Blues in Chicago and released on November 22, 2005. It was nominated for Best Rock Album at the 49th Annual Grammy Awards, with album artwork designed by Seattle's Ames Bros.

liveAlbums.description:
Where the Light Is: John Mayer Live in Los Angeles is a live album and concert film by John Mayer, released on July 1, 2008. It captures his performance at the Nokia Theatre in Los Angeles on December 8, 2007, during the promotional tour for his 2006 album Continuum. The concert features three distinct sets: an acoustic performance with Mayer and his band’s guitarists, a set with the John Mayer Trio, and a final set with his regular touring band.

The title comes from the song "Gravity," which was a single from Continuum. The album was released in multiple formats, including CD, LP, digital download, DVD, and Blu-ray, with bonus content featuring backstage footage and Mayer playing outside on Mulholland Drive.

Mayer's acoustic cover of "Free Fallin'" was critically acclaimed and released as a single. However, two songs, "No Such Thing" and "Bigger Than My Body," were performed but not included in the final release. "No Such Thing" was omitted due to Mayer singing an incorrect lyric, and "Bigger Than My Body" was likely left out because of a timing issue during the performance.

studioAlbums.description: John Mayer's debut studio album, released in 2001 and re-released later that year. It reached number 8 on the US Billboard 200 and received positive reviews, earning Mayer a Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance for the hit "Your Body Is a Wonderland." The album is Mayer's best-seller, with over 4.4 million copies sold in the US by 2014.

John Mayer's second studio album, released on September 9, 2003, by Aware and Columbia Records. The album debuted at #1 on the US Billboard 200, selling over 317,000 copies in its first week. While some critics pointed out flaws in Mayer's songwriting, the album received mostly positive reviews.

tracks.title: Waiting on the World to Change
I Don't Trust Myself (With Loving You)
Slow Dancing in a Burning Room

studioAlbums.description: Continuum is John Mayer's third studio album, released on September 12, 2006. It was produced by Steve Jordan and features a blend of blues and soul influences, marking a shift from Mayer's previous pop rock style. Bassist Pino Palladino joined Mayer, with whom he had previously toured as the John Mayer Trio. The album debuted at number 2 on the US Billboard 200, selling over 300,000 copies in its first week and more than 5 million worldwide. It received critical acclaim, winning Grammy Awards for Best Pop Vocal Album and Best Male Pop Vocal Performance. Rolling Stone ranked it among the top albums of 2006 and later listed it at number 486 in their 2020 list of the 500 Greatest Albums of All Time.

tracks.title: All We Ever Do Is Say Goodbye
Half of My Heart ft. Taylor Swift

studioAlbums.description: John Mayer's fourth studio album, released on November 17, 2009, by Columbia Records. The album was produced by Mayer and Steve Jordan and recorded between February and August 2009 at various studios, including Battle Studies recording studio in Calabasas, California, Capitol Studios in Hollywood, and The Village in West Los Angeles. It debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200, selling over 286,000 copies in its first week. The album received positive reviews and achieved platinum status, having sold over 880,000 copies in the United States. It produced two charting singles.

tracks.title: If I Ever Get Around to Living

studioAlbums.description: John Mayer's fifth studio album, released on May 22, 2012, by Columbia Records. It marked yet another change in Mayer's musical style, incorporating elements of folk and Americana, as well as influences from Bob Dylan, Neil Young, David Crosby, Stephen Stills, and Graham Nash. Its cover, as well as that of the single 'Queen of California', was designed by David Adrian Smith. Born and Raised received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised Mayer's technical skills as well as Don Was' production work. The first single 'Shadow Days' was released on Mayer's blog on February 27, 2012, and was made available for purchase as a digital download on March 6, 2012. The second single 'Queen of California' impacted Hot AC radio on August 13, 2012, and the third single 'Something Like Olivia' impacted Triple A radio on November 5, 2012.

studioAlbums.description: John Mayer's sixth studio album, released on August 20, 2013, by Columbia Records, is musically similar to his previous album but includes more electric guitar instrumentation. The title refers to his home in Montana's Paradise Valley. Singles include 'Paper Doll', 'Wildfire', and 'Who You Love'.

tracks.title: Never on the Day You Leave
You're Gonna Live Forever in Me

studioAlbums.description: John Mayer's seventh studio album, released on April 14, 2017, by Columbia Records, is a concept album that explores the emotional journey of a break-up, beginning with the break-up and concluding with the girl getting married.

tracks.title: I Guess I Just Feel Like
All I Want Is to Be with You

studioAlbums.description: John Mayer's eighth studio album, Sob Rock, was released on July 16, 2021, by Columbia Records. The album includes the single 'New Light' (2018), along with his 2019 singles 'I Guess I Just Feel Like' and 'Carry Me Away.' The lead single, 'Last Train Home,' was released in June 2021 and features Maren Morris. Mayer toured the U.S. with Dead & Company in 2021 and began a solo tour in 2022 to support the album.
